channel.title: Bloomberg Markets
channel.copyright: Copyright 2025 BLOOMBERG L.P. ALL RIGHTS RESERVED

item.title: Wealth Manager: Chinese Investors Look to Diversify
item.description: Grant Pan, Noah Holdings CFO and ARK Hong Kong CEO, says wealthy Chinese investors have become more sophisticated. Pan says clients are now looking at markets such as Japan, Singapore and Europe to diversify. It's a change from high net worth individuals who were previously more focused on China and the US. He discusses this trend with Yvonne Man and Annabelle Droulers on "Bloomberg: The China Show." (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Former Australian Prime Minister Turnbull on Chinese Ownership of Darwin Port
item.description: Former Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull discusses Chinese ownership of the Port of Darwin in an interview with Bloomberg Television. Turnbull says "our assessment at the time was that this wasn't a security issue," but adds that the shifting geopolitical landscape means "there's a discomfort about a Chinese company owning port facilities" in the country. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Stocks Edge Down After Weak Bond Auction in Japan: Markets Wrap
item.description: Asian shares made modest moves as investors avoided taking long-term risky bets ahead on US payrolls data Friday.
item.dc:creator: Anand Krishnamoorthy

media:content.media:description: The Marriner S. Eccles Federal Reserve building in Washington, DC, US, on Wednesday, Aug. 21, 2024. Chair Jerome Powell will usher in the next chapter in the Federal Reserve's inflation battle on Friday, when he's expected to set the table for an interest-rate cut while reassuring investors that policymakers can stave off a sharp economic slowdown.

item.title: Oil Holds Decline as Saudi Arabia Seeks More Major Output Hikes
item.description: Oil held a drop on signs Saudi Arabia is seeking another big production increase at next month’s OPEC+ meeting, in a bid for market share that could worsen a glut expected later this year.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: A flame burns from a stack at the oil processing facility at Saudi Aramco's Shaybah oil field in the Rub' Al-Khali desert, also known as the 'Empty Quarter,' in Shaybah, Saudi Arabia, on Tuesday, Oct. 2, 2018. Saudi Arabia is seeking to transform its crude-dependent economy by developing new industries, and is pushing into petrochemicals as a way to earn more from its energy deposits. Photographer: Simon Dawson/Bloomberg

item.title: ECB to Cut Rates as Trade Mess Weighs on the Economy
item.description: The European Central Bank is set to lower interest rates for an eighth time as President Donald Trump’s jolts to global trade dim the prospects for inflation and the economy.
item.dc:creator: Jana Randow

item.title: Oil Investments to Fall 6% on Lower Demand and Prices, IEA Says
item.description: Global oil investments are expected to drop 6% in 2025, in the first such decline in a decade excluding the year of the Covid slump, according to the International Energy Agency.
item.dc:creator: Nayla Razzouk

media:content.media:description: Pipes near fuel and crude oil storage tanks at the Galp Energia SGPS SA Sines refinery plant in Sines, Portugal, on Tuesday, March 25, 2025. Galp expects its biofuels and green hydrogen projects located at the Sines refinery will be operating in mid-2026. Photographer: Goncalo Fonseca/Bloomberg

item.title: Japan 30-Year Bond Auction Sees Weakest Demand Since 2023
item.description: Japan’s 30-year bond auction saw the weakest demand since 2023, ramping up pressure on the government to adjust issuance.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass

item.title: Neuberger Berman Raises $4 Billion for New Secondary Fund
item.description: Neuberger Berman has raised more than $4 billion for its latest general partner-led secondary fund despite a challenging environment for private capital fundraising.
item.dc:creator: Swetha Gopinath

media:content.media:description: A pedestrian near the New York Stock Exchange (NYSE) in New York, US, on Thursday, April 10, 2025. Risk appetites vanished on Wall Street after the biggest burst of buying in years, with stocks falling even after subdued inflation data extended a bounce in Treasuries. Photographer: Michael Nagle/Bloomberg

item.title: Laopu Gold’s 2,300% Rally Faces Test After Stock Hits HK$1,000
item.description: A breathtaking rally in Laopu Gold Co. is facing a critical test after its stock price hit HK$1,000 ($127), a rare milestone that may deter retail investors due to the steep price tag.
item.dc:creator: John Liu, April Ma

media:content.media:description: Gold jewelry on display at a Laopu Gold Co. store.

item.title: This Might Be the ‘Biggest Year’ in Tech: Bosworth
item.description: Meta CTO Andrew Bosworth speaks at Bloomberg Tech San Francisco 2025 about why this year could be pivotal for the development of the metaverse, highlighting unique opportunities emerging for engineers across the tech industry. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Japan’s Bonds Back on Stage With Another Sale of Longer Debt
item.description: Japan’s sovereign debt is back in the spotlight as the government prepares for another sale of super-long-term bonds after dismal showings at recent auctions, as demand for the far-end of the curve sputters across the globe.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Hidenori Yamanaka

media:content.media:description: The Sunshine 60 building, top center, and other buildings in Tokyo, Japan, on Friday, Feb. 14, 2025. Japan is scheduled to release its fourth-quarter gross domestic product (GDP) figures on Feb. 17.

item.title: President Trump Signs Travel Ban for 12 Countries
item.description: President Donald Trump has signed a proclamation that bans individuals from 12 countries from entering the US. Bloomberg's John Harney reports on the latest from Washington. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Meta CTO on What's Ahead in Artificial Intelligence / DAY 1
item.description: Andrew “Boz” Bosworth, Chief Technology Officer & Head of Reality Labs at Meta spoke about harnessing engineering talent and his leadership priorities at Meta, including what’s next for a hardware rollout in the AI era with Bloomberg’s Tom Giles at Bloomberg Tech in San Francisco. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Enterprise Products Says US Set to Deny Its China Ethane Export License
item.description: Enterprise Products Partners LP received a notice saying the US intends to deny licenses for three proposed cargoes of ethane heading to China as the Trump administration doubles down on security for exports to the country.
item.dc:creator: Emma Sanchez

media:content.media:description: A gas processing facility operated by Enterprise Products Partners LP stands in Yscloskey, Louisiana, U.S., on Tuesday, Sept. 7, 2010. Enterprise Products Partners LP, the largest U.S. pipeline operator, agreed to buy Enterprise GP Holdings LP for more than $8 billion, combining two of the partnerships founded by the late billionaire Dan Duncan.

item.title: Glencore-Backed Cobalt Holdings Axes $230 Million London IPO
item.description: Cobalt Holdings Plc has decided not to proceed with its planned initial public offering in London.
item.dc:creator: Charles Capel, Mark Burton

media:content.media:description: Structures used for processing raw cobalt at a mine near Lubumbashi, the Democratic Republic of Congo.

item.title: Bargain Hunters Scouring For Distressed Sectors May Eye India's Road Developers
item.description: Before the trading day starts we bring you a digest of the key news and events that are likely to move markets. Today we look at:
item.dc:creator: Ashutosh Joshi

item.title: China Drafts Rules for Driver Assistance Systems to Boost Safety
item.description: China is developing new mandatory national safety requirements for driver assistance systems, signaling a move toward tightening regulations as the safety of the rapidly evolving technology comes under scrutiny.
item.dc:creator: Charlie Zhu, Chunying Zhang

media:content.media:description: A Xiaomi SU7 WANG ZHAO/AFP via Getty Images)

item.title: Vingroup Seeks Private Loan to Buy KKR’s Stake in Vinschool
item.description: Vietnamese conglomerate Vingroup JSC is seeking an around $300 million private credit loan to purchase KKR & Co.’s stake of about 38% in its education subsidiary Vinschool, according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Megawati Wijaya, Giang Nguyen

media:content.media:description: A student enters Vinschool within Vinhomes Ocean Park complex in Hanoi, Vietnam on Tuesday, June 11, 2024. According to Bloomberg Intelligence, Vinhomes, Vingroup's residential development arm, is likely to continue to replenish its order book with mega launches and is planning to launch projects in Hanoi, Ho Chi Minh City and Hai Phong in 2025-26.

item.title: People Use Google by Choice, Says CEO Pichai
item.description: Alphabet Inc.’s Chief Executive Officer Sundar Pichai talks about the US Justice Department's antitrust case against the search giant. Pichai says choice is good for users, but he says "the reason people use Google is because they want to use it." He speaks to Bloomberg's Emily Chang at the Bloomberg Tech summit in San Francisco. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Alphabet's Pichai on AI, Antitrust Suits, Privacy
item.description: Alphabet Inc.’s Chief Executive Officer Sundar Pichai spoke with Bloomberg’s Emily Chang in a wide-ranging interview on artificial intelligence, antitrust lawsuits filed against the company, and how they work to protect user data. They speak at the Bloomberg Tech summit in San Francisco. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Kimberly-Clark Nears Global Tissue Business Sale, WSJ Says
item.description: Kimberly-Clark Corp. is close to a roughly $3.5 billion sale of its global Kleenex and tissue businesses outside of North America, the Wall Street Journal reported, citing unidentified people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Karen Leigh

item.title: Saudi Arabia Cuts Oil Prices for Asia as OPEC+ Adds Barrels
item.description: Saudi Aramco cut the price of its main oil grade to buyers in Asia after OPEC+ continued with its outsized output increases for a third month.
item.dc:creator: Yongchang Chin, Alex Longley, Anthony Di Paola

media:content.media:description: Crude oil storage tanks at Saudi Aramco's Ras Tanura oil refinery and oil terminal in Ras Tanura, Saudi Arabia.

item.title: Why Property Giant New World’s Debt Woes Have Hong Kong on Edge
item.description: Bankers in Hong Kong are on edge as New World Development Co., one of the city’s top real estate developers, attempts to pull off an HK$87.5 billion ($11.2 billion) refinancing deal by the end of the month.
item.dc:creator: Shawna Kwan, Pearl Liu

media:content.media:description: The K11 Atelier building, developed by K11 Group Ltd., a unit of New World Development Co., in Hong Kong.

item.title: Google Works Hard to Earn Trust of Users, Pichai Says
item.description: Alphabet Inc.’s Chief Executive Officer Sundar Pichai talks about the evolution of artificial intelligence and how it protects the data of users. He speaks to Bloomberg's Emily Chang at the Bloomberg Technology Summit in San Francisco. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Blackstone Leads $1.5 Billion Financing for Baker Tilly Merger
item.description: Blackstone Inc. led a private credit deal of around $1.5 billion to support Baker Tilly’s merger with Moss Adams, according to a person with knowledge of the matter.
item.dc:creator: Ellen Schneider

item.title: BofA’s Hauner Expects More Emerging-Market Gains as Dollar Drops
item.description: Emerging-market assets look poised to deliver “several percent” returns this year on expectations of a continued decline in the US dollar, according to Bofa Securities.
item.dc:creator: Subhadip Sircar

item.title: South Korean Bonds Pressured by Lee’s Fiscal Spending Agenda
item.description: South Korean bonds are facing tougher times ahead, as concerns grow that the country’s left-leaning new president will usher in an era of fiscal expansion accompanied by rising government debt.
item.dc:creator: Jaehyun Eom

item.title: China’s Power Prices Nosedive in Relief to Tariff-Hit Factories
item.description: A crash in Chinese coal prices, and a flood of clean energy, are cutting power rates in major industrial hubs, easing pressure on some of the factories caught in the crossfire of trade hostilities with the US.
item.dc:creator: Dan Murtaugh, Kathy Chen

item.title: Singapore’s AAA Bills Offer an Opportunity for US Carry Trade
item.description: Some of the safest assets in Asia offer investors a yield pickup to Treasuries in the wake of the US losing its last AAA credit rating.
item.dc:creator: Catherine Bosley, Masaki Kondo

item.title: Gold Holds Gain as Soft US Data Bolster Bets on Fed Rate Cuts
item.description: Gold held gains, after weaker-than-expected US data reinforced expectations that the Federal Reserve will cut interest rates at least twice this year to prevent a recession.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

media:content.media:description: One kilogram gold bars at the ABC Refinery smelter, operated by Pallion, in Sydney, Australia, on Thursday, April 17, 2025. Gold paused its record-breaking rally amid optimism over US-Japan trade talks, after bullion earlier reached another all-time high. Photographer: Brendon Thorne/Bloomberg
